overview: How to take legal action if someone owes you money, how much it will cost, and what happens after you make a claim through the courts
title: Make a court claim for money

table.body:
If someone owes you money and won't pay, you can take court action against them. This is known as making a court claim.

You usually have to pay a court fee, and you may not win your case or get your money back.

A [mediation service](http://www.civilmediation.justice.gov.uk/ "mediation service"){:rel="external"} could be quicker and cheaper than going to court.

^Mediation is when an impartial person helps two sides work out an agreement.^

##How to take court action

If you still want to take court action you can either:

- use [Money Claim Online](/make-money-claim-online/ "Money Claim Online")
- download a [claim form](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=338 "claim form"){:rel="external"}

You may have to go to a court hearing if the other person or business denies owing the money.

If they admit owing the money or don't respond, you can get the court to order them to pay.

If they still won't pay, you'll need to ask the court to take extra steps to collect the money - eg using bailiffs. This is called enforcing a judgment.

##Where to send the claim form

Send the claim form to:

$A County Court Money Claims Centre  
PO Box 527  
Salford  
M5 0BY $A

You'll need to include payment for the court fee.
table.title: Overview

table.body:
The court fee is based on the amount you're claiming, plus interest.

Using Money Claim Online will be cheaper than sending a claim form to the County Court Money Claims Centre.

| Claim amount | Sending form to court centre | Using Money Claim Online
| -- | -- | --
| Up to £300 | £35 | £25
| £300.01 to £500 | £50 | £35
| £500.01 to £1,000 | £70 | £60
| £1,000.01 to £1,500 | £80 | £70
| £1,500.01 to £3,000 | £95 | £80
| £3,000.01 to £5,000 | £120 | £100
| £5,000.01 to £15,000 | £245 | £210
| £15,000.01 to £50,000 | £395 | £340
| £50,000.01 to £100,000 | £685 | £595

Pay by credit or debit card if you're using Money Claim Online.

If you use the claim form, pay with a postal order or cheque (payable to 'HM Courts & Tribunals Service').

%You may have to pay more fees later on - eg if there's a court hearing, or you need to get a judgment enforced.%

You may be able to claim the costs back if you win the case.

Find out more about [court fees](/court-fees-what-they-are/ "court fees").
table.title: Court fees

table.body:
You can claim interest on the money you're owed.

If you're owed money by another business, you can charge [interest on a late commercial payment](https://private-frontend.production.alphagov.co.uk/late-commercial-payments-interest-debt-recovery-costs/charging-interest-commercial-debt?edition=1 "interest on late commercial payment").

For other types of debt, the rate is usually 8%.

To calculate this, use the steps below.

s1. **Work out the yearly interest:** take the amount you're claiming and multiply it by 0.08 (ie 8%).
s2. **Work out the daily interest:** divide your yearly interest from step 1 by 365 (the number of days in a year).
s3. **Work out the total amount of interest:** multiply the daily interest from step 2 by the number of days the debt has been overdue.

$E**Example**

If you were owed £1,000:

- the annual interest would be £80 (1000 x 0.08 = 80)
- you'd divide £80 by 365 to get the daily interest: about 22p a day (80 / 365 = 0.22)
- after 50 days this would be £11 (50 x 0.22 = 11)$E
table.title: Work out interest

table.body:
The person or business who owes you money must respond to your claim within 14 days of receiving it.

##What to do if you get paid

If they pay you, or make you an offer you're happy with:

- tell them you're withdrawing your claim
- [contact the court centre](http://hmctscourtfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/Search.do?court_id=1459 "contact the court centre"){:rel="external"} to let it know you're ending the case

##If you don't get a response

If they don't respond to your claim, ask the court to order them to pay.

To do this:

- use [Money Claim Online,](http://www.moneyclaim.gov.uk/web/mcol/welcome/ "Money Claim Online"){:rel="external"} (if you started your claim online) or
- fill in a [request for judgment form](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=465 "request for judgment form"){:rel="external"}

##How to take your claim to court

You may have to go to a court hearing if:

- the person or business says they don't owe you any money
- they disagree with the amount
- you can't agree on how the money will be repaid

The court will send you a [questionnaire,](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=384 "questionnaire"){:rel="external"} asking for more information on the case. Fill this in and return it to the court.

You will have to pay extra [court fees.](http://hmctscourtfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetLeaflet.do?court_leaflets_id=264 "court fees"){:rel="external"}

##Agreeing without going court

You can still talk to the other person or business, and try to reach an agreement before the court hearing.

Use the court's small claims mediation service if your claim is worth under £5,000 - contact your [local county court.](http://hmctscourtfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/ "local county court"){:rel="external"}

If you settle out of court before the hearing, you may be able to get some of your court fees refunded.

%The judge might not award you costs if they think you've made no effort to agree out of court.%
table.title: After you make your claim

table.body:
You may have to go to court if the other person or business denies owing the money, and they defend the case.

##Small claims

If your case is a small claim - under £5,000 - it may be dealt with using written evidence, without a hearing.

If there is a hearing, you can:

- represent yourself
- pay for a solicitor to represent you
- ask someone to speak on your behalf, like your partner or an advice worker - you must get the court's permission

^Small claims hearings can be held in the judge's room or a court-room at the defendant's local county court.^

##Cases worth more than £5,000

If you're claiming for more than £5,000, there may be a more formal hearing, and you should get legal advice.

##After the hearing

The court will send you a letter giving you its decision.

If you disagree with the decision, you have 21 days from the date of the decision to appeal. The letter will explain how to do this.
table.title: Going to court

table.body:
If you win your case, you may have to ask the court to take steps to collect the payment.

You will have to pay extra court fees - ordering someone to attend court costs £50, and the other steps cost £100 each.

##Find out what the person or business can afford to pay

It's worth working out what the person or business can afford to pay.

You can ask the court to [order a debtor to attend court](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=547 "order someone to attend court"){:rel="external"} to provide evidence of their income or spending, like bills and statements.

If the money is owed by a business, you can ask for an [officer from the company](http://hmctsformfinder.bl.justice.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=551 "officer from the company"){:rel="external"} to attend court, to give details of its accounts.

You can then decide on what you need to do to get your money.

##Send bailiffs to collect payment

You can ask the court to use bailiffs to collect the money.

To do this:

- fill in a [warrant of execution form,](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=555 "warrant of execution form"){:rel="external"} or
- use [Money Claim Online](http://www.moneyclaim.gov.uk/web/mcol/welcome/ "Money Claim Online"){:rel="external"}

The bailiff will ask for payment within 7 days. 

If the debt isn’t paid, the bailiff will visit the person's home or business, to see if anything could be sold to pay the debt.

##Get money deducted from wages

You can ask the court to send an order to the person's employer, to take money from wages to pay the debt.

To do this, fill in an [attachment of earnings order.](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=567 "attachment of earnings order"){:rel="external"}

##Freeze assets or money in an account

The court can freeze money in the person's bank or building society account (or in a business account).

To do this, fill in a [third party debt order.](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=573 "third party debt order"){:rel="external"}

The court will decide if money from the account can be used to pay the debt.

##Charge the person's land or property

You can ask the court to charge the person's or company's land or property.

To do this, fill in a [charging order.](http://hmctsformfinder.direct.gov.uk/HMCTS/GetForm.do?court_forms_id=576 "charging order"){:rel="external"}

If the land or property is sold, they must pay this charge before they get their money.
